perturbation.original_text:
15.3 Governing Law. This Agreement shall be interpreted and enforced in
accordance with the laws of the State of California as applied to agreements
made, entered into and performed entirely in California by California residents,
notwithstanding the actual residence of the parties, without giving effect to
any choice of laws of California that would require the application of the laws
of a state other than California.
perturbation.changed_text:
15.3 Governing Law. This Agreement shall be interpreted and enforced in
accordance with the laws of the State of California, specifically excluding
California's Uniform Commercial Code (UCC), even if the agreement involves
transactions that would normally fall under the UCC's scope. The parties agree
that principles of equity and general contract law, as interpreted outside the
UCC, will govern all aspects of this agreement, notwithstanding the actual
residence of the parties.
perturbation.explanation: This change directly contradicts established legal principles. The UCC is the primary body of law governing commercial transactions in California. Excluding it from the governing law, even when applicable, creates a legal contradiction because the UCC would normally apply to contracts involving the sale of goods or other commercial activities. It creates legal uncertainty and potential unenforceability, especially in disputes regarding sales, warranties, or other commercial aspects of the agreement. California Civil Code Section 1646 mandates the agreement to be interpreted per the laws of the state (including the UCC).
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Uniform Commercial Code (UCC), California Civil Code Section 1646
